{"comments": {"id": 26933, "count": 68, "talk_id": 2313}, "threadId": 26933, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "2313", "description": "Swallowing pills to get medication is a quick, painless and often not entirely effective way of treating disease. A potentially better way? Lasers. In this passionate talk, TED Fellow Patience Mthunzi explains her idea to use lasers to deliver drugs directly to cells infected with HIV. It's early days yet, but could a cure be on the horizon?", "event": "TED2015", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Patience Mthunzi: Could we cure HIV with lasers?", "slug": "patience_mthunzi_could_we_cure_hiv_with_lasers", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "2496", "slug": "patience_mthunzi", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Patience", "lastname": "Mthunzi", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Laser scientist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/4ca7c110be21a6b741432bd3a019975603676f35_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Patience Mthunzi wants to use lasers to deliver medicines more effectively.", "whylisten": "

Patience Mthunzi is a research group leader at the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research in Pretoria, South Africa. There, she uses laser "tweezers" to try and separate diseased cells from healthy ones. She's also developed a way to use laser pulses to target drug delivery into cells.

Born in Soweto, Patience got her PhD in physics from the University of St. Andrews in Scotland. In 2012, she was named one of 20 Youngest Power Women in Africa by Forbes magazine; that same year she was given the Order of Mapungubwe for her contribution in the field of biophotonics. She's also a TED Fellow.

effectively.", "whylisten": "

Patience Mthunzi is a research group leader at the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research in Pretoria, South Africa. There, she uses laser "tweezers" to try and separate diseased cells from healthy ones. She's also developed a way to use laser pulses to target drug delivery into cells.

Born in Soweto, Patience got her PhD in physics from the University of St. Andrews in Scotland. In 2012, she was named one of 20 Youngest Power Women in Africa by Forbes magazine; that same year she was given the Order of Mapungubwe for her contribution in the field of biophotonics. She's also a TED Fellow.

author: Patience_Mthunzi;
title: Could we cure HIV with lasers?

aws-transcripts.transcript: What do you do when you have a headache, you follow an aspirin, but for this pill to get to your head where the pain is, it goes through your stomach, your intestines. In various other organs, Fist swallowing pills is the most effective and painless way off delivering any medication in the body. The downside, though, is that swallowing any medication leads to its dilution. And this is a big problem, particularly in HIV patients when they take their anti HIV drugs. These drugs are good for lowering the virus in the blood and increasing the city for cell count. But they're also notorious for their adverse side effects, but mostly bad because they get diluted by the time they get to the blood and Wes by the time they get to the sites where in mirrors most within the HIV viral reservoirs. These are areas in the body, such as the lymph nodes, the never system as well as the lungs where the virus is sleeping and will not readily get delivered in the blood off patients that are under consistent anti HIV drugs therapy. However, upon discontinuation off therapy, the virus can awake and in fact, new cells in the blood. Now all this is a big problem in treating HIV with the current drug treatment, which is a lifelong treatment that must be swallowed by patients. One day I set in thought, Can we deliver anti HIV vite directly within its reserve or sites without the risk off drug dilution? As a laser scientist? The answer was just before my eyes. Lasers off course, if they can be used for 10 history for diabetic wound healing and surgery that can be used for anything imaginable, including transporting drugs into cells as a mentor effect, we are currently using laser passes to poke or drill extremely tiny holes, which open and close almost immediately in HIV infected cells in order to deliver drugs within them. How is that possible? You may ask. Well, we shine a very powerful but super tiny laser beam on through the membrane off HIV infected cells. While these cells are immersed in liquid containing the drop, the laser pierces the cell. Why the cell swallows the drug in a matter off microseconds. Before you even know it, the induced whole becomes immediately repaired. Now we are currently testing this technology in the test tube or in Petrie dishes. But the goal is to get this technology in the human body, apply it in the human body. How is that possible? You may ask. Well, the answer is through a three headed device. Using the first head, which is our laser. We will make an incision to the site off infection. Using the second head, which is a camera, we meander to this side off infection. Finally using a fair head, which is a drug squatting sprinkler. We deliver the drugs directly at the site off infection, while the laser is again used to poke those cells open. Well, this might not that seem like much right now, but one day, if successful, this technology can lead to complete eradication off HIV in the body. Yes, A cure for HIV. This is every HIV research has dream. In our case, a cure led by lasers. Thank you.
